author: limesicle
title: Triplet
fandoms: 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia
summary: Midoriya Izuku grows up thoroughly believing that, just like a quirk, he doesn’t have a soulmate either. He’s right. He doesn't have one soulmate; he has two.
notes:
(See the end of the work for notes.)

I wanted a soulmate AU, and then I ended up with this.
text:
Midoriya Izuku finds out at a very early that the world is unfair. Quirkless– the first label he’s given on the playground. It stings–hurts, really–when he sees Katsuki standing opposite him instead of beside. It hurts more when Kacchan flings insults at him, but Deku stands up to him. He may not be strong, and he doesn’t have a quirk to fight back with, but he doesn't back down. The disparity between Deku’s strength of will and his fighting strength irk Katsuki to no end.

 

They stop being friends, but they grow up in close proximity. They grow up center of attention and stepped on. Deku grows up hounded at every turn by the only person he thought of as a friend. Katsuki hurls insults and puts a wall between them. Deku never questions it. He never questions why Katsuki is so sure of himself or why he looks down on people who are quirkless. He knows why. He knows he’s weak.

 

Deku learns to hunch his shoulders and make himself as small as possible. He stands up to Kacchan by refusing to run. Maybe it’s not the smartest thing to do, but he refuses to back down. He stops crying when Kacchan hits him. His breath stops hitching at every insult. He learns to listen and not take things to heart right away. (He does that later, when he’s alone in his room with the door shut and his mother sleeping soundly.)

 

When Deku gets a cold halfway through third grade. He doesn’t notice that Kacchan doesn’t touch him for those ten days. He doesn’t notice that all Kacchan does is yell “nerd’ at him as they pass in the hallway. He doesn’t notice the pair of red eyes that trail after him as he blows his nose into an overused tissue. The regular insults and getting shoved aside comes back when the cold goes away.

 

When they turn thirteen, Deku gets another label. Markless. The thirteenth birthday is around when everyone starts getting soulmarks. They appear small, just a single dot or a simple design. Girls appear in class with brightly-colored ribbons tied around theirs. Some of the boys use bandages to look cool. Other people use stickers to cover them. Very few people let the marks go in the open.

 

Deku doesn’t bother lying about it when people ask. No, he doesn’t have one. He checks himself in the mirror every morning. All that marks his skin are freckles.

 

Katsuki covers his with a bright red bandage, proudly holds it up so people see he has it, but doesn’t answer a single question about who it is. Deku tries to keep his eyes on his notebook and not on the red fabric around Katsuki’s right hand. He gets used to it in time, but his eyes still catch on crimson when he lets his thoughts wander.

 

Markless. Deku considers putting a bandage over some random place. His arm maybe or telling people it’s on his hip where they won’t bother to look. He doesn’t. He knows bullies. They might just use it as an excuse to humiliate him further, so he keeps his head down. Markless. The questions of “did you get it yet” die out, but the label stays.

 

They grow up Kacchan and Deku–two boys who dream of nothing but being heroes. They’re two boys who look at the same view of the world with different lenses. They’re the two boys, first from their school, who get into Yuuei.

 

The last year of junior high, Deku pretends he doesn’t notice that stops talking to him. There are no passing shouts of “fucking nerd” or “quirkless” as they pass each other. He doesn’t know if it bothers him. He puts all his energy into becoming a hero. He walks down the hallway completely invisible. Katsuki and the boys who follow him around are the only ones who ever talked to him.

 

He doesn’t know if Katsuki’s silence is a good thing or if it’s unsettling. Except he does. Deku is good at going through and figuring things out. He’s figured out how to look at his feelings and how to reason them out and then stuff them away if he needs to.

 

The next time he sees Katsuki, it’s at the entrance exam. They’re seated by school in the large auditorium, and the few centimeters between them has never felt so far. Maybe something will change. (It already has.)

 

Katsuki makes his friends and Deku makes others. And, yes, he actually makes friends. He’s grown up keeping his mouth shut, but now he doesn’t have to. He has a powerful quirk through the miracle known as All Might and people are looking at him with something other than contempt in their eyes.

 

In Yuuei class 1-A he’s Deku, no longer quirkless but vying for top-of-the-class. They haven’t talked about soulmarks yet. He doesn’t ask his classmates about it, and they don’t ask him. Katsuki has long ago taken to wearing gloves that cover the spot the strip of red cloth once did.

 

Villains start making their move, and Deku fills his mind with ways to get stronger. He trains hard and harder. Deku takes up his name and wears it proudly. Katsuki meant it as an insult, but that doesn’t matter now. Deku. It’s short and simple, and it’s a name he wore through childhood and through whatever life threw at him. He’ll carry that name through his teenage life, and through the foreseeable future. It’s his name now.

 

Deku finds Todoroki Shouto. He adds him to his growing list of friends by blowing through his insecurities. Deku ends up losing their fight, but he wins something better. Their bond is strong battle-forged and battle-tested. By the beginning of their second year, they’re Shoucchan and ‘Zuku.

 

The villains grow stronger, but so do the heroes. Izuku trains hard every day to control his quirk. It’s difficult, but he’s improving. Deku studies hard and trains harder. He manages to make friends and keep them even in the busy and competitive classroom. They may end up vying for the same spots as the world’s heroes one day, but he still wants to be friends with them. Maybe that’s only because he grew up alone.

 

Ochako becomes one of his best friends in class and out. She’s the first person to bring up soulmarks in their class. She mentions it suddenly when they have a free moment.

 

“Iwanttoshowyoumysoulmarktoseeifyouknowwhoitis,” she says.

 

Deku blinks at her and asks her to repeat it. He does his fair share of talking quickly, but it’s still not easy to understand. He puts down the pencil he’d been using to scribble notes on heroes and looks up at her. The pink on her cheeks is more pronounced than usual, and she doesn’t make eye contact the way she usually does. Ochako takes a deep breath and forces herself to look Deku in the eye.

 

“I want to show you my soulmark, to see if you have any ideas of who it is.”

 

The color in Deku’s face rises quickly, and he stammers that he has no experience and is probably not the person anyone should ask because he doesn’t have one and–

 

“You don’t?” She asks, surprised.

 

Deku’s face falls. He didn’t want to talk about it, didn’t mean to bring it up. Now he’ll gain that label again. Markless. When he looks up, he’s surprised to see the smile on her face.

 

“You can still fall in love, you know? Or maybe it’s just late, like your quirk.”

 

He nods. He can’t tell her his quirk isn’t something he was born with. She’s trying to comfort him, and he’s grateful for that.

 

“Can I still show you mine?” She asks.

 

He nods again. Sure .

 

Ochako rolls up the sleeve of her Yuuei uniform past her elbow, and turns her arm toward Deku.

 

“Here.” She points.

 

There’s a green mark on her arm. It doesn’t quite have a shape, and Deku has no guesses as to what it might be. It looks like a photograph that’s out of focus. Marks change. They grow in response to the person they’re on and the person their for. They’ll change when the two people meet, and they’ll change when the two people interact, and they’ll change even more when the two realize. It will focus someday and then she’ll know.

 

“I’m sorry, I don’t know,” he mutters.

 

Ochako bites her lip and walks away, rolling her sleeve back down to recover the mark. Katsuki snaps a pencil in half behind him. Deku turns around, and just catches the glare he’s given. A shiver runs down his spine. He didn’t do anything.

 

Katsuki corners him the next day. It’s a situation he hasn’t experienced for a while, but Deku instinctively presses himself against the wall and shrinks down. It’s habit by now. He hesitatingly looks up to see an angry glare, though for Katsuki, that’s normal.

 

“Are you really markless?” Kacchan growls.

 

“Yes,” he nods. He doesn’t have a reason to lie.

 

Katsuki chews on his lip and turns away. “Fucking useless,” he spits.

 

Deku thinks he hears a little something other than anger. Maybe he’s just imagining it. Katsuki probably has some reasons.

 

Second year continues between normal classes and the occasional skirmishes villains. After their big face-off against All For One in their first year, the villains seemed to be recuperating. They’re coming back in force.

 

The school struggles to keep their doors open. Eventually, they decide to give the hero class students to use their quirks if they’re threatened. It’s not a good solution, but it makes them more confident. They don’t have to run away if confronted. They’re supposed to contact a pro hero if possible, but they don’t have to worry about getting in trouble if they need protect their lives.

 

Deku lands in the hospital for the upteenth time. It’s not too bad. When he wakes up, he sees Shouto perched on the end of his bed. He’d been somewhere else for the fight. The moment Deku stirs, Shouto’s eyes open. There’s the greeting of “you’re awake.” Shouto smiles softly. It’s not something that happens often, but Deku treasures it every time it does. He can sympathize with Shouto. After all, they both grew up alone, though for very different reasons. So he appreciates those smiles that he knows can’t come easily. He returns it as best he can, and Shouto promises to bring him notes from the day’s classes.

 

Ochako comes to him a few days after he gets out of the hospital with a smile on her face. “I figured out what my mark was.”

 

It takes a full minute for Deku to process what she’s talking about. He’s been so preoccupied by training and One for All that he’s all but forgotten about soulmarks. When he does, he reads the smile on Ochako’s face.

 

“Who is it?”

 

She rolls up her sleeve again. It’s no longer blurry but clear. A green frog sits on her arm. As he looks at it, the frog sticks out a pink tongue and blinks at him. It reminds him clearly of another member of their class. Deku looks up at his friend.

 

“A-asui?”

 

Ochako nods, her face brighter by the second.

 

“Have you–?”


Ochako nods faster.

 

“So are you–?”

“She kissed me!” Ochako exclaims.

 

Then buries her face in her hands. Her forehead, that’s still visible, is very, very pink. Not that Deku isn’t, too. They both burst into a fit of embarrassed laughter, that only stops when someone slams down their notebook on the desk behind them. Deku turns to see Katsuki sulking. Ochako goes to her seat quietly. Deku stares at Kacchan for another moment before turning back to his own notes. They were being noisy, true, but Kacchan’s reaction seems out of place. Then again, it’s Bakugou Katsuki. Deku shrugs to himself and turns around.

 

He can’t shake the feeling that there’s a pair of eyes boring holes into him. He tucks his head into his elbow, and does his best to ignore the glare. Someone pokes him the shoulder a moment later. It’s Shouto–Shoucchan. Deku is still thinking about soulmates and soulmarks so he says something he wouldn’t normally.

 

“What do you think’s the latest anyone’s developed a soulmark?”

 

Shouto looks at him like he’s grown three heads, but he also flushes slightly. Deku starts to backtrack, with “it doesn’t matter.” Shouto settles in his seat, still turned towards Deku. They were allowed to pick seats when second year began. Katsuki sits directly behind Deku, and Shouto chose one next to him. Ochako sits on his other side.

 

“I never really thought about it,” Shouto answers, when he recovers from the initial shock.

“I see.” A sigh.

“Do you want to see mine?” Shouto leans on the table, chin in his hands.

“Wha–nonono, it’s fine, you don’t have to–”

 

Shouto looks away. “I don’t mind,” he says almost too quickly.

“Yesplease.”

“After class, then.” Shouto turns away.

“Wait why?”

 

Shouto looks up at him. His face is a little pink, and somehow Deku feels his chest flutter at that. Wait what? Deku turns back to his desk, trying to settle his heartbeat and hope that his face isn’t as red as it feels.

 

“It’s here,” Shouto answers, tapping his chest with his hand.

 

Deku lights up like a traffic signal. Yeah, later sounds good. A lot later. Later when his heart rate is under control. Halfway through class, he can’t think about the lesson at all. Everyone laughs when the teacher has to call his name twice for him to notice. He only looks up because Shouto prods him from the side with his foot.

 

After class, he follows Shouto out into the hallway. There are too many people there. Shouto’s not exactly self conscious, but it’s not really appropriate to unbutton his shirt in the hallway. They end up in a bathroom five minutes later. Deku presses himself into a corner of the stall and Shouto leans against the other. Come to think of it, the last time he was in bathroom stall was when Kacchan decided it would be fun to stick his head in a toilet. Fun times–for the blond, at least. Deku tries to keep his gaze somewhere other than his friend.

 

“Sorry, about this,” Shouto mutters, nodding to the cramped walls.

 

His hands fumble with his tie and the buttons of his jacket and hands them to Deku. Deku folds them over his arm keeping his gaze down. He tries not to think about what exactly they’re doing or what anyone else would think if they walked in. Shouto clears his throat.

 

“You can look now, ‘Zuku,” he murmurs.

 

Deku turns towards his friend and feels his face heat up again. It’s some comfort that Shouto, too, is more than a little pink. Izuku’s eyes trace down Shouto’s chest and then stop. The mark is in the center of his chest, basically over his heart. It’s a bright red spiky star that stands out against his skin. Lines swirl around the star. They glow with energy, sparking as Deku looks.

 

“That looks like my–” Deku starts, then slams a hand over his mouth. His eyes dart up quickly.

 

“It’s your quirk,” Shouto says. “I guess I wanted you to know.”

 

Shouto reaches for the hem of his shirt to close it again at the same time as Deku reaches his palm forward. They freeze. Shouto slowly lets go of his shirt again.

 

“Go ahead,” he prompts.

 

Deku presses his palm flat against Shouto’s chest. Shouto’s skin is warm. The lines of energy seem to glow brighter and the points of the star-like shape sharpen. There’s a steady pulse under Deku’s palm. It’s steady, but fast. Deku realizes what he’s doing and pulls back like he’s been given an electric shock.

 

“Sorry, Shoucchan, I didn’t mean…um…”

“It’s fine.”

 

Deku looks to the side silently as Shouto re-buttons his shirt, and hands his friend back his tie and uniform jacket. Shouto finishes, but neither of them makes another move.

 

“I’m your soulmate,” Deku mumbles.

“Yeah.”

“But I don’t have a…”

“I don’t care. I” Shouto places a hand on his shoulder. “I wouldn’t care if you weren’t my soulmate at all. I think I–”

 

And of course, then is when the door is blasted off it’s hinges. Because Bakugou Katsuki has impeccable timing and great self-control.

 

“What the fuck?” The blond slams his hands against the wall, against each of the stall walls. “What the fucking shit is going on here?”

 

“None of your business, Bakugou,” Shouto says stepping in so he edges in front of Deku.

 

Katsuki mirrors him. Deku stutters both their names, but Katsuki doesn’t look and Shouto doesn’t waver.

 

“Yes, it fucking is,” Katsuki spits.

 

He lifts his hands exposing his palms–the gloves he usually wears blown to pieces along with the door. There are twin marks on the palms of his hands. Each has a sort of blurry gold shape in the center, but each is surrounded green circles. When he looks more closely, he sees that there are words in the lines. After a moment of reading, he realizes that the words are random notes about heroes–things he’s probably muttered at some point or other.

 

Suddenly, Deku has two boys towering over him–one furiously flaming and the other staring with an unreadable sort of expression.

 

“It’s really fucking obvious this is yours. It even started out a disgusting little green lump.” Kacchan clenches his fist.

 

“I’m sorry,” Deku answers quickly, and it sounds more like a question than it should.

 

He startles when Katsuki slams his fist against the side of the stall. “It’s not your fault. I fucking hate how you try to take responsibility for every single fucking thing.”

 

They’re dragged back to the the classroom by the teacher. Katsuki sticks his hands deep into his pockets so no one can see his palms. Deku briefly wonders why he used to only cover his right hand, but is way too terrified to ask. Katsuki goes through the rest of the day yelling a little louder than usual, and keeping his hands under the desk. He gets detention for destroying school property. Shouto hardly talks to Deku for the rest of the day, and voices a hardly-audible goodbye as he leaves.

 

Izuku watches Ochako and Asui walk to the school gates together. He’s happy for them, he really is, but he doesn’t want to think about the mess of his own soulmates. Maybe getting the quirk from All Might somehow screwed it up. Or maybe Shouto and Katsuki are somehow mistaken. Deku has never considered himself to be one for a relationship. It would make sense, really, if he didn’t have one. Yes, that must be it.

 

Deku starts shrinking again when he sits in class. He still trains as hard as he can, but he talks a little less to his classmates. He wants to, but he’s not sure what he would say to them. Ochako has less time for him, but she still greets him cheerily every morning. He spends more time with Iida when he can. Deku purposefully looks away from Shoucchan’s seat next to him and ducks his head whenever Kacchan is around. He thinks it’s fine, until Ochako pulls him aside.

 

“It’s not good if the top three in class don’t even look at each other. What happened?” She looks concerned, and Deku can’t quite face her. “I thought you were friends with Todoroki-kun.”

 

Deku worries his bottom lip. He was friends with Shouto. He was friends with Katsuki, too, long, long ago. He glances nervously at Ochako’s concerned expression. The problem is he doesn’t know what to do. No clue. From what he’s heard about marks, they come in pairs. If he doesn’t have one, and both Shouto and Katsuki have his, where does that leave them? He hates making Ochako worry, so he bites his lip.

 

“I’ll talk to them,” he promises.

 

The moment the words are out of his mouth, he regrets it. Now he really has to talk to them. Shoucchan is quieter, but still possibly very, very terrifying and Kacchan is–well–he’s Kacchan. He doesn’t have a chance to start a conversation with either one of them for the rest of the day. He intends to look for Shouto first. They’re better friends, or were. Luckily or unluckily, they find him first.

 

“Deku, are you really fucking sure you don’t have a mark?”

 

They’re standing outside of Yuuei at the end of the day. Deku presses himself into the side of the school building–still a habit.

 

“I’m curious, too,” Shouto adds, much more gently than Katsuki. “When was the last time you checked?”

“Shoucchan, um, well…istoppedcheckingbecauseitwasn’tshowingupI’msorry.”

 

Shouto looks at him with a hint of sadness. “Do you remember what I told you?”

 

Deku flushes. Yeah, he remembers. Katsuki glares at both of them. He probably heard that part, too.

 

“For the record, I fucking hate both of you–”

“I know,” Deku replies. “I…I know that.”

“I’m not fucking finished!” Katsuki interjects. Deku pushes into the wall a little more.

“I’d really fucking hate it though if I didn’t have to see your dumbass faces every day.”

 

His face colors. “Fuck!” He slams a hand onto the wall right next to Deku’s head.

 

Shouto squeezes in next to Katsuki. “I meant what I said–I don’t care if we’re soulmates or not. I’m in love with you.”

 

“Todoroki, what in the fuck–”

“I was here to talk to him first, Bakugou.”

“Like hell you were! He’s not yours, fucking half-and-half asshole.”

 

Deku shoulders his way between them before they start fighting. “Stop!” They stop.

 

“Kacchan, I’d hate it if i didn’t see you every day, too, and Shoucchan, I really like you, but if you have a soulmate…sh-shouldn’t you find them?”

 

Shouto shakes his head. “It doesn’t matter. I might never find them, after all.”

“But–”

“It’s my choice, isn’t it?” He asks with a hint of a smile on his lips.

 

“Okay, fuck. I don’t hate you, okay? And there’s no way I’m about to fucking lose to Todoroki.” Kacchan elbows his way back in.

“It’s not up to us,” Shouto says, pushing back.

“Choose,” Kacchan says, turning to Deku.

“Huh?” There’s not a way for him to press any further into the wall. “I, I like you–both–Um, I can’t do something like that–pleasedon’tkillmekacchan.”

 

Katsuki turns to walk off angrily.

 

“Wait! Um…” Both of them turn to stare at Deku again. “I–well,–I thought maybe you could check me? For a mark. If it’s there, maybe it would help.”

 

Deku’s fingers fumble at his school jacket. Shouto instinctively takes it when he pulls it off. Kacchan kicks the wall, not making eye contact. Deku’s fingers fumble more as he reaches the buttons on his shirt. He hands that to Shouto, too, who’s now staring off to the side and hiding his reddening face with one hand. Deku glances down his chest, trying not to think about how exposed he is. They’re all guys, but– still.

 

“I don’t see anything,” he says hesitantly.

 

Shouto glances at him, then quickly looks away, the color of his face deepening. “What about your back?”

“My–uh, I haven’t checked.” He turns around, crossing his arms over his chest. “Is there anything?”

 

Deku tries to look over his shoulder, but he can only catch a sort of glimpse and has no idea what it is. The other two have a perfect view.

 

The first answer Deku gets is Kacchan’s “Fucking fuck!”  The second is Shouto’s quiet “so it’s both?”

 

“What, uh, what is it?” Deku asks, still trying to see what it is.

“Put your fucking shirt back on first.”

 

He takes it back from Shouto, and buttons it clumsily. Katsuki kicks the wall.

 

“Everything involved with you is so fucking complicated, Deku.”

“Shut up, Bakugou.”

“How the fuck are you okay with this?”

 

Shouto sighs. “It’s supposed to be the three of us, okay?”

 

Katsuki’s eyes widen. He looks purely surprised for a moment, then they settle into his more usual expression of anger.

 

“Fuck!” Kacchan punctuates the word with another kick to the wall.

 

Shouto turns away from the angry blond. “‘Zuku, the choice is still yours…your mark looks like both mine and…his, but it’s your choice. I’ll accept it.”

“Sh-Shouchan.” Deku looks up, then bites his lip and looks away again. “I need to th-think about this. I’m sorry!”

 

He slips away sideways, and runs home. He can’t look his mother in the eye as he pushes the door open. He glances once at the shape that twists around her wrist, and bites back any questions he has. He’ll figure it out somehow. Somehow. Maybe. But he knows he can’t keep running.

 

Midoriya Izuku is kept up that night by whirling thoughts. He’s closer to Shouto. They’re better friends. But it’s not like he considers Katsuki an enemy. In fact, when he tries to think about a life where he doesn’t hear Katsuki’s “fucking nerd” at least once a week, it makes his stomach turn. When he thinks about Katsuki, he usually thinks about Katsuki yelling at him or pushing up against walls or punching him. Or angry with him–and that’s almost worse.

 

When morning comes, he goes to school with dark shadows under his eyes and an attention span worse than it was in first grade. Shouto has to prod him several times before he answers the teacher’s questions, and he can feel Katsuki’s eyes drilling holes in him from the back. At lunch, he third wheels at Ochako and Asui’s table. Ochako asks him once if he’s talked to Katsuki or Shouto yet, but stops when she sees the borderline-traumatized expression on his face. She leaves him a pat on the shoulder and a “it’ll work out.” He dearly hopes that’s true.

 

The next day is Sunday, and they have the day off. Sometimes, he’d hang out with one of his friends, but Deku doesn’t feel like it this week. He hears that Kirishima and Katsuki are hanging out, and he hangs his head. If Katsuki and Shouto forget about him, he’ll understand. Maybe it would be easier that way. Deku shakes his head. He can’t think like that. He’ll work it out with his soulmates–both of them.

 

An hour later finds him standing in the bathroom twisted around so he can see his back. At first, he can’t believe what he’s seeing. It’s so gorgeous. How could something that looks like that possibly be part of him?

 

There are wings that slope from his shoulderblades, one of fire, one of ice. A large circle of light hovers between them and countless other smaller ones sparkle across his back. As he looks, one of the stars explodes. There’s no question of who the fire and ice is for.

 

He reaches his hands around his shoulders to try and touch it. The flames wrap around his fingers. He can’t feel any warmth, but the way the flicker makes them look so real. One of the stars pops in response. It turns into a burst of orange and red before going back to white. When he looks at his face, he sees a smile. Maybe he really does like both of them.

 

Deku sighs and rests his elbows on the bathroom sink. It would be simpler if he only had one soulmate. Or even zero. He had managed to get used to that idea, but two? Is that even possible? When he thinks about it, he wouldn’t want to be parted from either of them. When he really thinks about it, he feels that way about a lot of his friends. But this is a different kind of doesn’t-want-to-be-parted.

 

He thought he had a crush on Ochako in their first year of high school, but the reddening of his cheeks stopped happening and the stutters in his heartbeat stuttered out. He likes her, of course, but not in anything other than a friendly sense. He figured out he liked Shouto. He doesn’t think he likes Katsuki in quite the same way. Or does he? His mind supplies him an image from training one day when Katsuki either blew up or ripped off his shirt. Okay, maybe he does like Katsuki the same way.

 

That doesn’t make things easier. The two don’t really seem to get along, and Deku is doubtful of whether they can learn. He remembers the red star-like shape on Shouto’s chest. That could be an explosion. That could be Katsuki’s. But Katsuki? He didn’t think the rest looked like Shouto’s. Or maybe it did. He can’t even remember it clealry now.

 

Deku spends the rest of Sunday at home and looks at old news reports. Watching the glory days of the heroes he grew up hearing about is comforting. He pulls finds the clip where All Might saves hundreds of people alone and watches that, too.

 

School returns on Monday. Deku slips a note onto Shouto’s desk with the words “Talk after school?” and sends a glance behind him to where Katsuki sits. Katsuki glares at him for a moment, and Deku knows he’ll be there too without even sending him a note.

 

That’s the plan, anyway, until the villains come crashing back into their lives. They’ve been lucky, really, to have a few weeks of peace. In his concern over soulmates, he nearly forgot about villains. Nearly. But now he’s almost thankful to have something else to focus on.

 

The number of teachers present at training sessions has been increased, and so has the security of the individual facilities, but the villains manage to get in anyway. Deku finds himself frozen to the spot when he comes face-to-face with All For One for the second time. His blood turns to ice. In the second he hesitates, Shouto and Katsuki surge ahead of him. He catches up in an instant. They stand, all three together, for a moment.

 

“Go help the others!” Deku yells, as he steps into the space between them.

 

He doesn’t have to look around to see their classmates fighting, to know that some of them are struggling. Their pro-hero teachers can’t be everywhere at once, so Izuku prioritizes the safety of his classmates and sends the people he trusts the most to fight with them and tip the scales.

 

“You better not fucking lose, before I come back to kick his ass!” Katsuki yells over his shoulder.

 

Kacchan’s yell bolsters his strength. And Deku can stand taller now and with a stronger heart.

 

“Be careful, ‘Zuku!”

 

Shouto leaves with a pat on Deku’s shoulder, and Deku almost wants to take hold of that hand and keep him from going. But he doesn’t. This is an enemy he’s destined to face. This is an enemy he has to face, even without All Might to stand next to him.

 

He should anticipate the near-fatal injuries and the narrow victories by now. It doesn’t matter that he has better control of his quirk and can use up to 10% of it without damaging himself. Sometimes, he doubts if 100% would be enough to let him win. They make it through with minimal injury–no one dies. They make it through with One For All and Deku’s self-sacrificing streak. They make it through with altogether too many yells of “fuck” from Katsuki. They make it through with Shouto’s hand-curse finally acting on Tomura.

 

They make it through but All For One escapes in the end. They’ve suffered too many injuries to send anyone after him. When Deku tries, he’s held back by two sets of arms. He just registers that there are two sets of warm hands before he collapses from exhaustion. He’s getting used to using his quirk, but he’s not there yet. He can’t draw out enough of it’s power. Really, they’re lucky not to have lost anyone this time.

 

Deku wakes up hours later in a hospital bed that’s more familiar than it should be. His eyes blink open under the bluish light that’s left on in the middle of the night. His body feels heavy, and there are bandages everywhere. He didn’t think he’d been hurt that badly, but maybe he hadn’t noticed in the heat of the moment. He tries to shift quietly, but there’s a warm weight by his stomach.

 

When he looks down, he sees the unmistakable half-white, half-red of Shouto’s hair. Shouto stirs in his sleep, and Deku freezes. He didn’t mean to wake his friend. As he looks longer, that position can’t be comfortable. Shouto is on the tall side, and his back is arched over.

 

“Shoucchan,” Deku says, his voice a lot hoarser than he expected.

 

His eyes meet Shouto’s mismatched half-asleep ones a moment later. Shouto blinks once, twice, and then sits up quickly, rubbing his eyes.

 

“‘Zuku, are you okay?”

“Y-yeah,” he answers quickly. “You?”

 

Shouto nods, suppressing a yawn. “Nothing Recovery Girl couldn’t handle. I’m just–” He yawns again. “Tired.”

 

Shouto’s eyes fall shut again, head still resting by Deku’s side. Without thinking, he reaches his bandaged hand to run through the red half of Shouto’s hair. He’s met with those mismatched eyes again.

 

“Ah, sorry, Shoucchan! I just–”

“It’s fine,” he answers with a tired smile. “I love you.”

“Shoucchan!”

 

Deku can feel his heart pounding in his chest, especially as Shouto leans into his hand. He can’t brush his fingers through Shouto’s silky hair like he would if he wasn’t bandaged within an inch of his life, but he can still feel the gentle weight. Shouto closes his own hand around Deku’s bandaged one, rubbing his thumb over the strips of cotton.

 

“Now go to sleep, we can talk to Bakugou in the morning.”

“Is he okay?”

“He was snoring obnoxiously when I checked.”

 

Deku laughs quietly. He’ll be okay. They’ll be okay. With those thoughts in mind, he drifts into a deep sleep.

 

They wake when a nurse comes in and gasps much louder than necessary at their proximity. Shouto gets sent back to his own room rather rudely, but he shrugs it off. Deku has to endure a lot more poking and prodding and some checking of bandages, but then he’s left alone again. When all the nurses and doctors are gone, he tests his legs slowly. He knows he’s not in good shape, but if he can find enough strength to walk over to Kacchan’s room, that’ll be enough. When he opens the door, he finds Shouto leaning against the opposite wall.

 

Shouto already knows where Katsuki’s room is, so it doesn’t take long before they’re standing in front of it. Deku hesitates, does he really want to see Kacchan? Yes, yes, he does. He opens the door and peers in side. Happy to see that the room is empty save for one very-angry looking blond, Deku opens the door the rest of the way.

 

“Kacchan–” A glare cuts him off mid-sentence.

“I’m already in pain, and now I have to deal with both of you fuckwads. Great.”

 

He doesn’t say anything about them leaving, though, so Deku takes that as a plus. He moves to stand at the foot of the bed, gaze darting from his childhood friend and then away.

 

“Agh, fuck, stop doing that!”

 

Deku’s gaze jerks to Katsuki, and he holds it there.

 

“If you have something to say, spit it the fuck out.”

Deku swallows. “Uh, well, I don’t think this is the time–”

“I don’t give a shit what you think. I’m fucking sick and tired of sitting here, and the dumbshit mark on my hands is getting fucking clearer. So talk, you fucking nerd.”

 

Deku looks at the floor.

 

“It’s supposed to be the three of us, right? So let’s…let’s try that.”

 

He feels Shouto’s arms close around his waist and his head rest on his shoulder.

 

“What the fuck? Stop that!” Katsuki gets out of bed with surprising speed and little care for the IV in his arm. “You better learn to share, half-ass.”

 

Katsuki stands a little in front of them, pointing a finger into Shouto’s face. Deku reaches his arms forward hesitantly to include Katsuki in their hug. The blond flinches at first, but doesn’t back away. He inches forward and raises his own arms to reciprocate, muttering a “I really fucking hate both of you.” Shouto’s eyes widen when he feels two hands on his back.

 

“Nice try, Katsu,” Shouto smirks.

“Who the fuck is ‘Katsu?’” He asks, burying his head in Deku’s unoccupied shoulder.

 

Deku laughs lightly into Katsuki’s chest, ignoring the angry mumbling in his ear. Katsuki breaks away first, hand going to his bandaged ribcage.

 

“Kacchan, are you alright?”

“I’m fucking perfect, now get in bed before you collapse.”

 

He drags Deku gently–well, sort of gently– to the hospital bed, ignoring all protests. They manage to settle, with a bunch of ouches and trying not to put weight on injuries. Deku’s head rests on Shouto’s chest, and Katsuki lies on his side, somehow managing not to fall off.


Maybe having two soulmates will work out, after all.
